meta_description: The premier institution for showcasing African American art, history and culture in the Pacific Northwest.
hours_text:
# Visit Us

The Northwest African American Museum is housed in the historic Colman School building (built in 1909) which overlooks a beautiful, sprawling green park, named after rock legend, Jimi Hendrix, in the heart of Seattle’s Central District. It’s just 2.3 miles or 10 minutes by car, from downtown. 

Free parking is available in our parking lot, directly outside the museum. Please park in museum parking only (labeled MUSEUM), as there is resident parking in the other spots. The museum is easy to access via public transportation as well. Please visit King County Metro Trip Planner for directions. 

info@naamnw.org  
(206) 518-6000

2300 South Massachusetts Street  
Seattle, WA 98144

* * *

## **Hours**

**2025**

Monday - Closed

Tuesday - Closed

Wednesday - Closed

Thursday - 10am to 5pm 

Friday - 10am to 5pm

Saturday - 10am to 5pm

Sundays - 10am to 5pm

* * *

## Admission

$10 for adults

$8 for Seniors (55+), College Students (ID Required), Educators, Military, AARP

$5 for youth 18 and under 

Free for children three and younger

accessibility_text:
# Accessibility 

The Northwest African American Museum is committed to creating inclusive and accessible experiences for all people to feel welcome and safe. The museum is a single story experience and wheelchair accessible throughout. The upper two floors of the Colman School building are Low Income Housing provided by [the Urban League of Seattle](https://urbanleague.org/urban-league-village/). 

To request a reasonable accommodation or discuss your needs, please contact [access@naamnw.org](mailto:access@naamnw.org).

## Accommodations

  * Wheelchair accessible parking spaces are located nearest to the building in the Residential Side Parking area. 

  * Electronically assisted doors are located at the Main Entrance. 

  * Courtesy wheelchairs are available on a first come, first serve basis.

  * Accessible restrooms and stalls are located on the North and South sides of the building. 

  * Baby changing stations are located on the North and South sides of the building. 

  * Single stall all-gender Restrooms are located on the North side of the building. 

  * Closed captioning is available on videos in the Journey Gallery and Community Living Room. 

access@naamnw.org  
(206) 518-6000 ext. 100

2300 South Massachusetts Street  
Seattle, WA 98144

collections_text:
## King Day at NAAM 

[ ](/king-day)

NAAM invites the community to gather in honor of the life and legacy of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for a free public celebration rooted in courage, history, and collective action. Programming details will be announced soon, but expect a full day of reflection, creativity, and connection.

[ Learn More ](/king-day)

## Interactive Story Time 

Enjoy a reading of **_Martin’s Big Words: The Life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr._** , written by Doreen Rappaport and illustrated by Bryan Collier. This powerful picture book biography introduces young readers to the extraordinary life and enduring message of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., bringing his story to life through expressive collage art and Dr. King’s own words.

[ ](https://forms.gle/rQeB3NeZLweG54f66)

### Who Makes Change for You?

Share your story of the everyday heroes who inspire you — mentors, teachers, healers, and community builders. Your voice helps extend the History Lives Here tribute and reminds us that history lives in all of us.

[ Share Your Story ](https://forms.gle/rQeB3NeZLweG54f66)

**Click to Donate to NAAM or Become a Member Today!**

[ Donate to NAAM ](https://www.naamnw.org/donate)

[ Become a Member ](https://www.naamnw.org/become-a-member)

Follow [@NAAMNW](https://www.instagram.com/naamnw/) on Instagram

[ ](https://www.instagram.com/p/DTd7x1qleI_/)
